Location: Butabika, Kampala, Uganda
services: The hospital provides general and specialized mental health treatment for mental health patients and is a teaching hospital for a broad range of mental health specialists, from nursing to Post – Graduate students. Finally, Butabika Hospital is an important platform for research into mental health trends in Uganda, and approaches to tackling the problem.

services: Care Services, Our cancer experts at Uganda Cancer Institute treat both adults and childhood cancers. The diagnosis and treatment of your cancer often require the skills of many specialists. We bring together these specialists in a single setting (called multidisciplinary care). Here they discuss care for each patient and develop a thorough treatment program as a team. This provides you the best treatment plan possible. services: Busolwe General Hospital, located in the heart of Busolwe Town, Butaleja District, is a public hospital owned by the Ugandan Government and administered by Butaleja District Local Government. Location: Iganga, Iganga District, Uganda
services: Iganga General Hospital is a 100-bed, government-owned hospital. It serves Iganga District and parts of the districts of Luuka, Mayuge, Bugiri, Namutumba and Kaliro.[6] It was built in 1968.[3] Over the years, the underfunded, understaffed hospital's infrastructure has deteriorated and the hospital equipment has aged and become antiquated. The overworked staff are underpaid and of low morale.

Location: Itojo, Ntungamo District, Western Region, Uganda
services: Itojo Hospital today is somewhat run down despite attempts to improve its condition, notably the Egyptian government who have not only donated cash for renovations but have also provided specialist medical officers. The hospital, with a catchment area covering large swathes of Ntungamo district, is constantly under stress seeing more than 500 inpatients and 300 outpatients daily despite being built with just a 100-bed capacity. To run as planned, Itojo Hospital requires 198 staff but there are only around 140 employed, mostly support staff, and just four doctors out of the needed fifteen. With such bed and staffing shortfalls, many seeking medical attention are forced to wait or sleep on the floors of the crowded wards waiting for care from the overstretched medical staff meaning that patients frequently die before even being seen by a doctor. The hospital is the only facility where surgery can be performed in the area and it is also the centre to which the 47 health units in the district refer when treatment is beyond their means. More complicated cases are referred to Mbarara Regional Referral Hospital, located 36 miles away. Itojo faces other challenges such as an X-Ray machine that hasn't worked for years and an accumulated unpaid electricity bill of some 42,000UK (although that's still just 10% of the money embezzled from the hospital in 2012 by its then medical superintendent from funds meant to support cervical cancer surgeries in Ntungamo district.

services: Kalisizo General Hospital is government regional referral hospital with a bed capacity of 120.[1] The hospital treats many cases of malaria, particularly among children.[5] As with most government hospitals in the country,[6] Kalisizo hospital has challenges related to lack of appropriate medical equipment,[7] lack of blood,[8] and lack of appropriate medicines.

Location: Kamuli, Kamuli District, Busoga sub-region, Uganda
services: The hospital is owned by the Ugandan Government and administered by the Uganda Ministry of Health. Despite facing numerous challenges, Kamuli General Hospital continues to provide essential healthcare services to the community.The hospital has a planned bed capacity of 100, but due to the high demand for services, many more patients are admitted, with some sharing beds or sleeping on the floor. The hospital provides a wide range of services, including outpatient and inpatient care, maternity services, surgery, and laboratory services. Patients can also receive HIV testing and counseling, as well as family planning services.Kamuli General Hospital faces numerous challenges, including corruption, inadequate staffing, poor remuneration, insufficient medication, and outdated medical equipment. However, despite these challenges, the hospital staff remains committed to providing quality healthcare services to the community.The hospital staff includes skilled doctors, nurses, and support staff who work tirelessly to ensure that patients receive the care they need. The hospital’s maternity ward provides a safe and supportive environment for mothers and babies, while the surgery department offers life-saving procedures to patients in need.
cleaned services: outpatient and inpatient care, maternity services, surgery, laboratory services, HIV testing and counseling, and family planning services.

Location: Kapchorwa, Kapchorwa District, Eastern Region, Uganda
services: Despite being congested and understaffed, the hospital has been able to provide quality healthcare services to its patients. In 2015, the Government of Uganda began partial rehabilitation of the hospital, starting with the renovation of the operating theatre, procurement of new equipment, and reconstruction of the TB and maternity wards. The hospital also had solar panels installed, providing reliable and sustainable energy for the hospital’s operations.In recent years, the hospital’s catchment population has increased significantly, with an estimated 900,000 people from Kapchorwa District and its neighboring districts, as well as patients from the Kenyan counties of Trans-Nzoia and West Pokot, receiving healthcare services from Kapchorwa General Hospital. However, the hospital faced a setback in September 2020 when over 50 staff members tested positive for COVID-19, resulting in the hospital’s temporary closure for two weeks. The hospital was reopened in early October 2020 after mitigation measures were put in place.

Kasese Municipal Health Centre III boasts of state-of-the-art medical equipment, skilled medical personnel, and a conducive environment for quick recovery.The hospital has been able to handle several emergencies, including the evacuation of more than 87 patients from Kilembe Mines Hospital due to flooding caused by River Nyamwamba bursting its banks. Kasese Municipal Health Centre III has been instrumental in providing medical attention to these patients and ensuring their speedy recovery.The hospital is well-equipped to handle all types of medical conditions, including surgical procedures. The medical staff is highly trained and experienced, ensuring that patients receive the best possible care. The hospital also has a pharmacy that stocks a wide range of drugs, making it convenient for patients to get their medication without having to travel long distances.

services: After the renovation, the hospital will have a new emergency department (casualty department), a new, larger outpatient department, a new building to house the diesel-powered electricity generator, a new placenta disposal pit, a new medical waste disposal pit, a laundry facility for patients’ families, a kitchen and dining room for patients’ families, ventilated improved pit latrines for patient families and outpatients, and two new staff houses.The construction started in February 2014 with an expected completion date in October 2015. As of January 2021, the hospital has a capacity of 109 beds, providing quality healthcare services to patients in need.While it is true that the hospital has not undergone any major renovations in recent times, it continues to provide much-needed medical care to the community. The hospital is owned by the Ugandan Government and administered by the Pallisa District Local Government, ensuring that the hospital is well-maintained and properly managed.One of the most remarkable achievements of Pallisa General Hospital is the fact that it has treated and discharged over 60 COVID-19 patients as of July 2021, despite not having an intensive care unit (ICU) or an oxygen generating unit. This is a testament to the dedication and resilience of the hospital staff, who have gone above and beyond to ensure that patients receive the care they need.It is important to note that the Government of Uganda signed a credit agreement with the International Development Association in August 2010, with the aim of renovating a number of General Hospitals and two Regional Referral Hospitals in Uganda, including Pallisa General Hospital. However, as of December 2019, those planned renovations had not been carried out yet.

services: Despite facing several challenges such as poor funding, corruption, and inadequate staffing, Tororo General Hospital has managed to provide critical medical services to patients in Tororo and beyond. The hospital is owned by the Uganda Government and administered by the Uganda Ministry of Health, and serves the general public. A recent study carried out at the hospital identified seven conditions associated with stillbirths and neonatal deaths. These conditions include prematurity of the baby, breech presentation, multiple gestation, cesarean delivery, low birth weight, antepartum hemorrhage, and cord prolapse. The rate of perinatal death at the hospital was higher than Uganda’s national targets, but the medical staff at Tororo General Hospital are working hard to improve this statistic.

Location: Buwenge, Jinja District, Eastern Region, Uganda
services: the hospital will be equipped with modern facilities, including a double-storied T-Block to house patient wards, a new, larger outpatient department, an emergency department, a hospital administration block, a diesel generator for electricity, and facilities for placenta disposal, biomedical waste disposal, laundry, and kitchen and dining for patients’ families. In addition, six new staff residences will be built, and ventilated, improved, pit latrines will be provided for patients’ families and outpatients.The hospital’s strategic location, approximately 28 kilometres north of Jinja Regional Referral Hospital, and 109 kilometres northwest of Mulago National Referral Hospital, makes it easily accessible to patients from nearby districts. Once completed, Buwenge General Hospital will offer quality healthcare services to the people of Eastern Uganda, thereby reducing the need for patients to travel long distances in search of medical attention.

Location: Bwera, Kasese District, Western Region, Uganda
services: Bwera General Hospital admits a large number of patients on a regular basis. In fact, during times of high demand, the hospital has been known to admit up to 300 patients. However, like many government hospitals in Uganda, Bwera General Hospital faces a number of challenges, including non-functioning equipment, under-staffing, poor funding, over-worked staff, and slow payment of staff. Despite these challenges, Bwera General Hospital remains committed to providing high-quality healthcare services to its patients. The hospital has a well-equipped Ebola treatment unit that played a vital role in treating patients during the 2018-20 Kivu Ebola epidemic that affected neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo. This unit is a testament to the hospital’s dedication to staying at the forefront of healthcare in the region.
cleaned services: inpatient and outpatient care, mental health services, radiology (X-ray and ultrasound), dental care, pharmacy services, eye care, emergency services, antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV/AIDS, treatment for non-communicable diseases (NCDs), tuberculosis (TB) treatment, orthopedic services, palliative care, maternity services, pediatric care, surgical procedures, mortuary services, maternal and child health services, and nutrition services.

Location: Kisubi, Wakiso District, Buganda Region, Uganda
services: CoRSU was established in 2009 as a private, non-profit, non-governmental organization in Uganda. CoRSU’s core mandate is to mitigate the debilitating effects of disabling physical conditions, by ensuring accessibility and availability of quality, preventative, curative, rehabilitative services for people with disability in Uganda and neighboring countries. CoRSU provides subsidized treatments (surgery and rehabilitation) for vulnerable patients and this is carried out through social assessment tools.

Location: 97 Bugwere Road, Mbale, Mbale District, Uganda
services: CURE Uganda is one of Africa’s leading pediatric hospitals for brain surgery and the treatment of neurological conditions. It provides minimally invasive endoscopic neurosurgical procedures and attracts surgeons from around the world to its prestigious CURE Neuro Fellowship Program. Hospital staff complete approximately 1,900 surgical procedures annually for children with conditions including hydrocephalus, spina bifida, brain tumors, and other neural tube defects. In addition to world-class clinical service, CURE Uganda ministers to the emotional and spiritual needs of patients and their communities.
cleaned services: neurosurgical, Hydrocephalus treatment, Spina bifida treatment, Brain tumor treatment, Neural tube defect treatment

Location: Entebbe, Wakiso District, Uganda
services: The hospital is a point of reference in Uganda for elective paediatric surgery, with operations planned in advance and organised through waiting lists in order to systematically tackle deep-set problems in Uganda and nearby countries. The hospital’s three operating theatres are used for surgery every day and improving the life chances of hundreds of patients every year. The opening of the Children’s Surgical Centre led to a tripling of the number of paediatric surgery beds in the country. Elective surgery mainly deals with birth defects, urological and gynaecological problems, abnormalities in the gastrointestinal tract, illnesses of the bile duct and cheiloschisis (or cleft lip, which affects one child in 800) and other pathologies of more general surgical relevance. The facility boasts 100,000 square feet (9,700 m2) of floor space, 72 beds – six for intensive care and 16 for sub-intensive care – 50 beds in the ward, one observation and stabilisation ward, six outpatient clinics, a diagnostic centre, a laboratory for analysis, a blood bank, a pharmacy, as well auxiliary services such as a canteen and a laundry. It also has a guest house: free-of-charge accommodation for patients and families coming from afar.
